definitions: having the greatest importance, influence, or priority among things
first in order of importance or rank rather than subsidiary
relating to or denoting an original sum of money invested or lent
examples: The principal reason for leaving was better career opportunities
Her principal concern involves the children's safety and education
She works as the principal investigator on the research project
The principal office handles all major corporate decisions
The principal amount of the loan remains unchanged
You must pay both principal and interest each month

definitions: acting in accordance with strong moral principles or ethical standards
based on or conforming to a fixed set of rules or principles
examples: She made a principled stand against corruption in government
His principled refusal to compromise earned widespread respect
They developed a principled approach to solving ethical dilemmas
The principled framework guides all our decision-making processes

definitions: capable of being printed or suitable for printing format
appropriate or decent enough to be printed in public media
examples: The document contains only printable characters and standard fonts
Please provide a printable version of the presentation slides
His response contained few printable comments about the situation
The interview yielded barely printable quotes from the celebrity

definitions: existing or coming before in time, order, or importance
taking precedence over other things in importance or urgency
examples: Prior experience in marketing is required for this position
The prior owner left the house in excellent condition
Prior commitments prevent me from attending the meeting tomorrow
Family obligations take prior claim on my weekend time

definitions: showing the colors of the spectrum as through a prism
having the shape or properties of a geometric prism
examples: The prismatic effect of water droplets creates beautiful rainbows
Prismatic crystals scattered light throughout the chandelier
The mineral forms distinctive prismatic crystals in volcanic rock
The building features prismatic glass panels on its facade

definitions: in perfect condition as if new or unused
remaining in its original state without human interference or damage
examples: The vintage car remains in pristine condition after forty years
She keeps her white sneakers looking absolutely pristine
They discovered pristine wilderness untouched by human development
The pristine coral reef shows no signs of pollution

definitions: belonging to or for the use of one particular person or group
concerning personal matters not to be disclosed to others
denoting the lowest rank of soldier in the army
examples: They held a private meeting behind closed doors yesterday
The beach is private property accessible only to residents
Please keep this private information strictly between us
Her private thoughts remained hidden in her diary
The private saluted his commanding officer and stood at attention
Three privates were promoted after completing their training

definitions: having special rights, advantages, or immunities not available to everyone
legally protected from being disclosed without consent in legal proceedings
examples: The privileged students attended elite private schools abroad
She grew up privileged but works hard to help others
Attorney-client conversations remain privileged and confidential communications
The privileged documents cannot be used as evidence

definitions: sharing in the knowledge of something private or secret
examples: Only senior executives were privy to the merger negotiations
She wasn't privy to their private conversation last night

definitions: highly valued or esteemed for excellence or special qualities
awarded as or suitable for winning a prize
examples: Her prize orchids win competitions throughout the country annually
The museum displays his prize collection of ancient coins
The prize bull sold for a record amount at auction
Their prize-winning roses bloom magnificently every summer

definitions: of professional rather than amateur quality or status
in favor of or supporting a particular cause or position
examples: She plays tennis at a pro level despite her young age
The pro tournament attracts top athletes from around the world
The senator took a pro environment stance on the legislation
Their pro democracy movement gained widespread international support

definitions: creating or controlling situations by taking initiative rather than responding after events
examples: Companies need proactive strategies to prevent security breaches
Her proactive approach to problem-solving impressed the management team

definitions: based on or involving probability theory rather than certainty
examples: The probabilistic model predicts weather patterns with reasonable accuracy
Scientists use probabilistic methods to analyze quantum mechanical systems

definitions: likely to happen or be true based on available evidence
examples: Rain seems probable given these dark storm clouds approaching
The probable cause of the accident was mechanical failure

definitions: relating to a trial period of assessment before permanent acceptance
examples: New employees undergo a six-month probationary period before permanent hiring
The probationary teacher received regular performance evaluations throughout the year

definitions: searching thoroughly and deeply into matters to discover information
physically exploring or examining by touch or with instruments
examples: The journalist asked probing questions about the scandal
Her probing analysis revealed hidden patterns in the data
The doctor's probing examination located the source of pain
Scientists use probing instruments to explore deep ocean trenches

definitions: presenting difficulties or causing problems that need to be dealt with
open to doubt or not definitely true or acceptable
examples: The problematic software update caused system crashes worldwide
Their problematic relationship affected the entire team's performance
These problematic assumptions undermine the study's conclusions entirely
The witness gave problematic testimony contradicting earlier statements

definitions: relating to official or established procedures or ways of doing things
examples: The committee handles procedural matters before discussing substantive issues
Television networks love procedural dramas about police investigations

definitions: subjected to a special treatment or procedure to preserve or modify
treated with chemicals or subjected to industrial procedures
examples: The processed data reveals interesting patterns about consumer behavior
Processed applications move to the next stage of review
Many people avoid processed foods for health reasons entirely
The processed cheese melts more smoothly than natural varieties

definitions: relating to or used in formal religious or ceremonial processions
examples: The processional hymn accompanied the bride down the aisle
Processional music played as graduates entered the auditorium

definitions: officially or publicly announced or declared with emphasis
describing oneself as something whether accurate or not
examples: The proclaimed winner celebrated victory before final results arrived
Their proclaimed policy contradicts their actual business practices
The self-proclaimed expert offered questionable advice to clients
Several proclaimed messiahs appeared during that turbulent period

definitions: spending money or resources freely and recklessly in a wasteful manner
having or giving something on a lavish scale without restraint
examples: His prodigal spending habits eventually led to bankruptcy
The prodigal son returned home after squandering his inheritance
Nature's prodigal display of autumn colors delighted the tourists
The chef's prodigal use of truffles made the dish extraordinary

definitions: remarkably or impressively great in extent, size, or degree
abnormally or amazingly large beyond what seems natural
examples: Her prodigious talent for mathematics emerged at age five
The project required prodigious amounts of time and resources
The storm produced prodigious waves that damaged the coastline
He consumed prodigious quantities of food after the marathon

definitions: producing or able to produce large amounts of goods or crops
achieving or producing significant results or benefits effectively
examples: The productive factory operates twenty-four hours every day
Productive farmland yields abundant crops throughout the growing season
We had a productive meeting that resolved several issues
She spent a productive afternoon organizing her research notes

definitions: showing disrespect or contempt for sacred or religious things
not relating to religion or religious matters but secular
examples: His profane language shocked the religious congregation members deeply
The profane graffiti on the church wall upset local residents
The museum displays both sacred and profane art together
Medieval writers distinguished between profane and religious literature

definitions: openly declared or acknowledged as one's belief or intention
claimed to be something but perhaps not genuinely so
examples: His professed love for classical music guides his compositions
Their professed commitment to sustainability influences company policies
The professed expert made several basic errors in analysis
Despite professed neutrality, the mediator showed clear bias

definitions: relating to or belonging to a particular profession or occupation
competent, skilled, or assured in performance or behavior
engaged in an activity as one's main paid occupation
examples: She sought professional advice from a qualified lawyer
Professional standards require continuing education in this field
His professional manner impressed clients during difficult negotiations
The professional presentation convinced investors to fund the project
Professional athletes train intensively throughout the year continuously
She became a professional musician after years of practice

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a professor in manner or appearance
examples: His professorial beard and tweed jacket completed the academic look
She adopted a professorial tone when explaining complex theories

definitions: competent or skilled in doing something through practice and familiarity
examples: She became proficient in Spanish after living abroad for years
The job requires someone proficient with database management systems

definitions: yielding profit or financial gain in business operations
beneficial, useful, or worth doing for advantages gained
examples: The profitable company expanded into new international markets
Their most profitable product line generates millions annually
She spent a profitable afternoon learning new programming skills
The profitable discussion led to breakthrough solutions

definitions: extending far below the surface or to a great depth
showing deep insight, understanding, or knowledge about something
very great, intense, or complete in degree or extent
examples: The submarine descended into the profound depths of the ocean
A profound silence filled the cathedral during prayer
Her profound understanding of human nature enriches her novels
The philosopher made profound observations about modern society
The medication had profound effects on his mental state
They expressed profound gratitude for the life-saving assistance

definitions: abundant, plentiful, or given freely in large amounts
examples: The garden displayed profuse blooms throughout the summer months
She offered profuse apologies for arriving late to dinner

definitions: relating to or serving as a prediction of future outcomes, especially medical
examples: Prognostic indicators help doctors estimate patient survival rates accurately
The prognostic value of these tests remains under debate

definitions: happening or developing gradually or in stages over time
favoring or promoting political or social reform and new ideas
denoting a verb tense expressing ongoing action
examples: The patient showed progressive improvement over several weeks
Progressive deterioration of the building necessitated major repairs
The progressive politician championed universal healthcare and education reform
Progressive companies embrace flexible working arrangements for employees
Students practice using progressive verb forms in English class
The present progressive tense indicates ongoing actions

definitions: formally forbidden by law, rule, or authority from being done
examples: Smoking is strictly prohibited inside all hospital buildings
Prohibited items will be confiscated at security checkpoints

definitions: so high in cost as to prevent purchase or use
serving to forbid, restrict, or prevent something
examples: The prohibitive cost of housing forces families to relocate
Prohibitive import taxes protect domestic manufacturers from competition
Prohibitive regulations stifle innovation in emerging technology sectors
The prohibitive nature of the rules discouraged participation

definitions: estimated or forecast to happen in the future
displayed on a surface using light or other means
examples: The projected earnings exceed last year's actual profits significantly
Projected population growth will strain urban infrastructure systems
The projected image appeared clearly on the conference room screen
Projected shadows created dramatic effects during the performance

definitions: designed to be projected or thrown forward through space
examples: The projectile weapon launched objects at high velocity
Ancient armies used various projectile weapons during sieges

definitions: extending outward beyond a surface or boundary line
planning or estimating something for the future
examples: The projecting balcony offers panoramic views of the city
Projecting rocks made the cliff face dangerous for climbers
The company is projecting substantial growth for next quarter
Scientists are projecting temperature increases over coming decades

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the industrial working class
examples: The proletarian movement gained momentum during industrialization periods
His proletarian background influenced his political philosophy significantly

definitions: producing much fruit, offspring, or creative work in abundance
examples: The prolific author published three novels every year consistently
Mozart was an incredibly prolific composer throughout his lifetime

definitions: continuing for a long time or longer than usual or expected
examples: The prolonged drought devastated agricultural production throughout the region
Prolonged exposure to loud noise can damage hearing permanently

definitions: projecting from something or standing out physically from surroundings
important, famous, or well-known in a particular field
examples: Her prominent cheekbones gave her face a striking appearance
The building's prominent tower dominates the city skyline
Several prominent scientists attended the international conference yesterday
She became a prominent figure in civil rights activism

definitions: having or involving many sexual partners without commitment
showing lack of discrimination in choices or indiscriminate mixing
examples: The novel portrayed the promiscuous lifestyle of 1920s society
Health educators discuss risks associated with promiscuous behavior
The promiscuous use of antibiotics creates resistant bacteria strains
Their promiscuous mixing of architectural styles created visual chaos

definitions: showing signs of future success or good results
examples: The promising young artist received a prestigious scholarship
Early test results look extremely promising for the new treatment

definitions: containing or conveying a promise or assurance of future action
examples: He signed a promissory note agreeing to repay the loan
The promissory language in the contract binds both parties

definitions: relating to advertising, marketing, or publicizing products or events
examples: The company launched a promotional campaign for their new product
Promotional materials were distributed at the trade show

definitions: done without delay or immediately when required or appropriate
arriving or acting exactly at the scheduled or proper time
examples: The company provided prompt responses to customer complaints
Prompt medical attention saved the accident victim's life
Please ensure prompt arrival for your morning appointment
The prompt payment of invoices maintains good supplier relationships

definitions: officially proclaimed, published, or made widely known by authority
examples: The newly promulgated regulations take effect next month
The promulgated decree changed taxation policies throughout the nation

definitions: likely or liable to suffer from, do, or experience something
lying flat with the face and front of body downward
examples: Children are particularly prone to ear infections during winter
The accident-prone worker required additional safety training
The patient remained prone during the back examination procedure
Soldiers learned to fire rifles from a prone position
